message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy and his sister have different expressions of the same genetic trait, which suggests variable expressivity. This means that the same mutation can have different effects on different individuals. Compound heterozygosity refers to the presence of two different mutant alleles at a particular gene locus, frameshift mutation refers to a genetic mutation caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides in a DNA sequence that is not divisible by three, and chromosomal instability refers to an increased tendency of chromosomes to break or exchange genetic material during cell division. None of these principles explain the observed differences in this pair of siblings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient and his sister both have the same genetic disorder, which is likely Marfan syndrome. However, the patient has lens subluxation and an arched palate while his sister does not. This is due to variable expressivity of the syndrome, meaning that individuals with the same genetic mutation can have different phenotypic presentations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. The boy and his sister both have Marfan syndrome, but the boy has more severe symptoms, such as lens subluxation and high-arched palate. This is an example of variable expressivity, which means that the same genetic mutation can lead to different symptoms in different individuals. Compound heterozygosity refers to the inheritance of two different mutant alleles of a gene from each parent, resulting in a non-functional protein. Frameshift mutation refers to the insertion or deletion of nucleotides in a DNA sequence, resulting in a non-functional protein. Chromosomal instability refers to the tendency of chromosomes to break or undergo abnormal segregation during cell division.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient and his sister both have Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene. Variable expressivity accounts for the fact that while both siblings have the mutation, they have different phenotypes. This means that the severity and range of symptoms can vary between individuals, even within the same family. The sister may have a milder form of the syndrome, which does not include lens subluxation or an arched palate. Compound heterozygosity, frameshift mutation, and chromosomal instability are not relevant to Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. Variable expressivity refers to the phenomenon where individuals with the same genetic mutation display varying symptoms or severity of symptoms. In this case, both siblings have Marfan syndrome, but only the younger brother displays lens subluxation and an arched palate, which are examples of variable expressivity. Compound heterozygosity refers to inheriting two different mutant alleles from each parent, frameshift mutation is a type of genetic mutation, and chromosomal instability refers to the tendency for chromosomes to break or rearrange during cell division. These principles do not apply to the phenotypical differences seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient and his sister have features of Marfan syndrome, which is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene. Variable expressivity means that individuals with the same genetic mutation can have different degrees of severity or different symptoms. This explains why the patient has lens subluxation and an arched palate while his sister does not have these features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has Marfan syndrome, which exhibits variable expressivity because some individuals with Marfan syndrome may have different features or different severity of symptoms than others with the same genetic mutation. The older sister may have inherited the Marfan gene but does not express all the associated features. Compound heterozygosity, frameshift mutation, and chromosomal instability do not apply to the situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. The presentation of Marfan syndrome in the siblings varies in degree, which is an example of variable expressivity. It is caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, but the presence of different variants of the mutation can lead to different phenotypic expressions. Compound heterozygosity refers to the presence of two different mutations on different alleles of a single gene, while frameshift mutation involves the insertion or deletion of nucleotides that alter the reading frame of the gene. Chromosomal instability refers to abnormalities in the structure or number of chromosomes. None of these principles explain the phenotypic differences observed in the siblings with Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. The patient and his sister both have features of Marfan syndrome, which shows variable expressivity, meaning that the severity and range of clinical features can vary among individuals with the same genetic mutation. This can result in differences in phenotypical expression of the syndrome between siblings. Compound heterozygosity refers to the presence of two different mutations on different copies of the same gene, while frameshift mutation refers to a mutation that results in a shift in the way the gene is read, and chromosomal instability refers to abnormalities in chromosome number or structure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. Variable expressivity is the phenomenon where individuals with the same genetic mutation can have different phenotypical expressions, causing one sibling to have different symptoms than the other. This is supported by the fact that both siblings have symptoms of Marfan Syndrome but only the younger sibling has lens subluxation and an arched palate, indicating variable expressivity. Compound heterozygosity refers to having two different mutations in the same gene or different genes, frameshift mutations involve the insertion or deletion of nucleotides that can change the reading frame of a gene, and chromosomal instability can lead to genetic disorders but none of these concepts apply to the scenario given.
